bibl.title: Fletcher Decker v. State of Washington. Extradition.
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image.

div1.p: IN THE DISTRICT OF THE UNITED STATES WESTERN DISTRICT NORTHERN DIVISION
IN THE MATTER OF THE EXTRADITION of FLETCHER DECKER.) ( )
No.
B R I E F opposing petition for WRIT OF HABEAS CORPUS
The proceedings before the commissioner were pursuant to the Extradition Treaties between U.S. and Great Britian of 1842 and 1889. For these treaties, see Malloy's Treaties, Vol.1, page 655 and 740.
The present hearing being one on Habeas Corpus before the District Court, the first inquiry is as to the scope of review of the District Court: on a habeas corpus hearing:

POWER OF DISTRICT COURT OF HABEAS CORPUS PROCEEDINGS TO REVIEW PROCEEDINGS OF THE COMMISSIONER IS LIMITED TO DETERMINING WHETHER THERE WAS ANY LEGAL EVIDENCE UPON WHICH COMMISSIONER COULD EXERCISE HIS JUDGMENT AND WHETHER ANY PROBABLE CAUSE EXISTED FOR COMMISSIONER BELIEVING PRIONER GUILTY.

In re Count De Touluse Lautrec, 102 Fed 879. Matter of Wahl, 15 Blatch. 334. Matter of Wiegand, 14 Blatch. 370. Ex p. Van Aernam 3 Blatch 160. Ex p. Van Hoven, 4 Dill 415. Terlinden vs Ames 184 U.S. 270. Bryant v. U.S. 167 U.S. 104. Ornelas vs. Ruiz 161 U.S 502. Fong Yue Ting vs U.S. 149 U.S. 698. In re Cortes, 136 U.S. 330. Benson vs. McMahon, 127 U.S. 457. Sternaman vs. Peck 80 Fed. 883. In re Fowler 4 Fed. 303. In re Veremaitre, 3 Am. L. J. N. S, 438 28 Fed. Cases No. 16,915. In re McDonell, 11 Blatch. 170, 16 Fed. Cas. No. 8772. In re Kaine, 10 N.Y. Leg. Obs. 257, 14 Fed. Cas. 7598. In re Stupp 12 Blatch. 501. Matter of Vandervelpen 14 Blatch. 137. In re Krojanker, 44 Fed. 482. In re Behrendt 22 Fed. 699.
Fed Case 16409
In re Wadge 16 Fed. 332 Grin vs Shine 187 U.S. 191 In re Herskovitz 136 Fed. 713. Ex parte Charlton 185 Fed. 880. Powell vs U.S. 206 Fed. 400. Ex parte Schorer 197 Fed. 78.
In re Herskovitz, 136 Fed. 713.
On petition for Habeas Corpus after proceedings before the Commissioner.

"By section 5270, already referred to, concurrent jurisdiction is given to the serveral officers named in the statute to issue warrants, hear exam- inations, and to commit in extradition proceedings. This, the, is a collateral attack upon the judg- ment of a concurrent court. It is too well settled to require the citation of authority that the writ of habeas corpus cannot be used as a method or fe- viewing proceedings as if upon error, and that judg- ments or findings of courts of competent jurisdic- tion cannot be set aside or avoided by this pro- cedure because of error. Under the provisions of the statute the commissioner had full jurisdiction of the subject-matter, and there is no question but what he had jurisdiction of the person of the petitioner. I think the disclosures made at the examination have, however, cured any defect in the complaint."
Powell vs. U.S. 206 Fed. 400
Defense attempted to prove absence from the foreign country at the time of the offense charged by the way of alibi, and alleged as error the refusal of the commissioner to entertain the defense.

"The commissioner also said orally upon the hearing, and in his return to the writ issued from the Dis- trict Court, that he did not disregard the testi- mony tending to show an alib, but gave it due con- sideration and did not believe it, and from the whole testimony drew the conclusion that there was probable cause to believe Powell guilty."
Ex parte Charlton 185 Fed. 880.

"The duty of the committing magistrate is confined to determining: First, whether such warrant or cer- tificate has been issued; second, whether the of- fense charged against the accused is extraditable un- der the treaty; third, whether the person brought be- fore him is the one accused of such crime; and, four- th, whether there is probably cause for holding the accused for trial, the evidence in that respect to be such as, according to the law of the state in which the accused is apprehended, would be sufficient to commit him for trial."
Sternam vs Peck 80 Fed. 883.

"A writ of habeas corpus cannot perform the office of a writ of error in reviewing the proceedings in extradition before an officer authorized to enter- tain such proceddings. It is efficent only to reach error which is fatal to the jurisdiction of the officer over the person of the accused, or over the subject-matter of the accusation...... .....The evidence was not very satisfactory, and was far from being convincing. Nevertheless, the facts and circumstances proved authorized conflict- ing presumptions and probabilities as to her guilt or innocence, and it was the province of the com- missioner to determine theri import, and whether they were such as to justify him in exercising his power to commit her to custody pending the action of the department of state."
In re Stupp. 12 Blatch. 501

The court issuing the writ of habeas corpus "is not to inquire whether the legal evidence of facts before the commissioner was sufficient or in- sufficient to warrant his conclusion; nor, if there was legal and competent evidence of facts before the commissioner, for him to consider in making up his decsion as to the criminality of the accused, is the court, on habeas corpus, to hold the proceedings il legal, and to discharge the prisoner, because some other evidence was introduced which was not legal or competent, but was held to be so by the commis- ioner, and was considered by him on the question of fact, or, because the court, on a consideration of all the evidence which the commissioner considered, would have come to a different conclusion, or be- cause the court on an exclusion of such of the evidence as it may think was not legal or competent, would come on the rest of the evidence, to a dif- erent conclusion of facts from that at which the commissioner arrived."
Grin vs Shine. 187 U.S. 181.
the sufficiency of the evidence cannotbe reviewed on habeas corpus.
Ex parte Schorer 197 Fed. 67.
The court, after discussing the lack of proof of intent, said:

"It is always possible to conceive that the accused might be an innocent victim of circumstances; but, if an extradition commissioner has drawn the per- missable inferences of guilt, it is beyond the prov- ince of the court on habeas corpus to reject them. We may note that the testimony given by the accused before the commissioner, although it consisted of denials, called for nothing more than the exercise of the commissioner's discretion in believing it or disbelieving it. It could not render incompetent the other testimony, and whether it was worthy of belief, whether the accused fairly met the incul- pasing circumstances with which he was confronted, was within the peculiar province of the commissioner to determine; and such determination is not review- able on habeas corpus."
TO JUSTIFY THE COMMISSIONER IN ISSUING THE CERTIFICATE HE NEED ONLY HAVE PROBABLE CAUSE FOR BELIEVING THE ACCUSED GUILTY.
Ex p. Charlton 185 Fed. 880. U.S. vs Piaza 133 Fed. 998. Ex p. Zentner 188 Fed. 344.
U.S.vsPiaza 133 Fed. 998.

"Authorities abound which hold that it is sufficient if the accused is held on competent legal evidence, and, further, if probable cause exists for believ- ing the defendant guilty of the offense charged. The evidence need not be conclusive, nor must the commissioner who hears the proceedings be absolute- ly convinced of the defendant's guilt, before exer- cising the power to commit him."
THE LEGALITY OF THE EVIDENCE.
Section 5271 of the Act is superseded by SECTION 5 of the Act of 1882.
3 Fed. Stats. Anno. page 90. In re Behrendt 22 Fed. 699. In re McPhun 30 Fed. 57.
This section provides for DEPOSITIONS, WARRANTS, or OTHER PAPERS.
and makes ALL SUCH legal evidence if properly auth- enticated showing admissability in the foreign country
In re Cortes. 42 Fed. 47.
The court may look to the warrant of arrest for a statement of the offense, and the prisoner can- not object if that sufficiently informs him of the offense.
In re Behrendt 22 Fed. 699.

"The certificate of the royal judge that the judicial proceeding certified to 'is valid evidence according to the laws existing in Prussia', reasonable inter- preted, can mean nothing less than that, according to the law of Prussia, such documents are valid evidence of criminality as regards the crime charged in the proceedings specified in the court where the proceedings purports to be had. This is all the evidence that is required under the first branch of the statute; since the proceedings appear upon the face to be acriminal one, in a criminal court."
In re Krojanker 44 Fed. 482.
Following the Behrendt case.
Terlinden vs Ames. 184 U.S.S 270. (184 U.S. 270)
In this case copies of the Penal Code of the German Empire were attached to the complaint.
In re Exeta 62 Fed. 972. (984-5(

Here, statements, in the form of depositions, but not even appearing to have been sworn to, were submitted. It was held that their infor- mality was covered by the Act of Congress and the certificate.
Elias vs. Ramirez. 215 U.S. 398.
Unsworn statements were admitted by reason of the Act and the fact that they created a probab- ility of guilt.
In re Luis Oteiz vs Cortes 136 U.S. 330.
Here informal papers, and ex parte depositions were offered by the defense under the Act and refused not because of their informality, but because of the fact that they were offered by the defense.
Ex parte Glaser 176 Fed. 702.
Following Elias vs. Ramirez. Supra.
Grin vs Shine 187 U.S. 191.
ORAL PROOF MAY BE TAKEN IN AIDER OF IRREGULARITY OR INSUFFICIENCY.
In re Folwer 4 Fed. 303.
In re Wadge 15 Fed. 864.

THE CERTIFICATE OF THE DIPLOMATIC OR CONSULAR OFFICER OF THE UNITED STATES RESIDENT IN THE FOREIGN COUNTRY IS ABSOLUTE PROOF THAT THE PAPERS CERTIFIED ARE RECEIVABLE IN THE FOREIGN COUNTRY AS PROOF OF CRIMINALITY.
In re McPhun 30 Fed. 57
In re Wadge XXXXXX 15 Fed. 864.
AND THE SIGNATURE OF THE UNITED STATES VICE CONSUL IS SUFFICIENT FOR THIS PURPOSE ALSO.
In re Herres 33 Fed. 165
In re Orpen 86 Fed. 760.
AND THE WORDING OF THE CERTIFICATE IS SUFFICIENT IF IT FOLLOWS THE LANGAUGES OF THE STATUTE.
Grin v. Shine 187 U.S. 181.

THEREFORE THE PETITIONER'S CONTENTION THAT THERE IS NO EVIDENCE OF THE COMMISSION OF A CRIME MUST FAIL BECAUSE THERE WAS COMPETENT LEGAL EVIDENCE BEFORE THE COMMISSIONER WHICH THE COMMISSIONER FOUND TO CREATE PROBABALE CAUSE OF THE COMMISSION OF A CRIME BY THE PRISONER AND HIS DECISION ON THIS POINT IS NOT OPEN TO REVIEW BY THE DISTRICT COURT IN THIS PROCEEDING.
It is next contended by the Petitioner that THE COMMISSIONER DID NOT HAVE JURISDICTION.

This contention cannot stand for the simple reason that the Comissioner did have jurisdiction, and reference to the papers will show that affirmatively, although it is the duty of this court to TAKE JUDICIAL NOTICE OF THE COMMISSIONER'S AUTHORITY AND JURISDICTION.
Ex parte Lane. 6 Fed. 34.
It is next contended by the Petitioner that the warrant is void and illegal.
This contention is unsound.
THE WARRANT MUST NOT NECESSARILY SHOW ON ITS FACE THE AUTHORITY OF THE COMMISSIONER.
This was decided in Ex parte Lane. 6 Fed. 34. (1881, Michigan, Dist. Ct. 6

In this case both the complaint and the warrant failed to show the power of the commissioner to act in extra- dition cases. After the close of the proceedings and without the knowledge or consent of the petitioner the complaint was amended by interlining "extradition" to show the authority.
The District Court Judge doubted the right of the amendment and determined the case as though unamended. Then, after reviewing the cases holding to the contrary, said:

"Hence, I think it should appear that the person taking the complaint and issuing the warrant is not only a commissioner of the court, but is one authorized to act iin extradition cases. I should be loth, however, to hold that the proceedings were void upon this account, since I am by no means certain but that the court, upon an application for discharge upon a writ of habeas corpus, would be bound to take judicial notice of the fact that the commissioner had been appointed for this purpose. If a third person had been indicted for resisting amarshal in the execution of this warrant, I should have no doubt that the decision of Justice Curtis would apply, and that it would be necessary to make a more particular averment in the indictment."

The reasonable and logical inference from this opinion is that if the commissioner had seen fit to let the accused go by reason of the defect in the warrant he might have done so, but actually having the authority, and the proceedings being otherwise regular, and there being evidence of guilt, he acted properly; and the District Court will ig- nore mere technicalities and take judicial notice of the fact that the commissioner actually had authority and acted within it by issuing the warrant.
This brings it exactly within the case at bar, on that point.

In the Lane case the Judge doubted the authority of the Commissioner to amend. But there the amendment was made after the close of the proceedings and without the know- ledge of the petitioner. But in the case at bar the warrant was amended at the opening of the proceedings and in the presence of counsel of both parties.

Inasmuch as there is a conflict of authority on this question, but has not been decided in this District or assed upon by the Supreme Court both the question as to the validity of the warrant and the power to amend must be open questions.

The first consideration is that the Act only requires the Commissioner to be authorised by any of the courts of the United States. It does not require the warrant to show the authority its face. (Sec. 5270).
The second consideration is that technicalities will be ignored and good faith will be kept with the foreign country.
In re Neely 103 Fed. 626.
In re Herres 33 Fed. 165 reversing 32 Fed. 583
In re Roth 15 Fed. 506.
